item.title: The Deprecation of K1 Mode
item.description: As the next step in the evolution of K2 mode, with the IntelliJ IDEA 2025.3 release we are officially deprecating its predecessor, K1 mode. In this post, we’ll give some background about K2 mode and discuss its current state, including adoption numbers, performance test results, and feature parity and stability. As always, we recommend updating […] Link to article: https://blog.jetbrains.com/idea/2025/12/the-deprecation-of-k1-mode/

item.title: Dev Proxy v2.0 with improved AI telemetry, and small breaking changes
item.description: We're excited to announce the release of Dev Proxy v2.0. Following semantic versioning (SemVer), we're bumping the major version due to breaking changes in this release. While these changes are small, they improve Dev Proxy's accuracy and behavior - and we want you to be aware of them. This release also br Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/microsoft365dev/dev-proxy-v2-0-with-improved-ai-telemetry-and-small-breaking-changes

item.title: Unlock GitHub Copilot’s Full Potential: Why Every Repo Needs an AGENTS.md File
item.description: Supercharge Your AI Pair Programming Experience with Project-Specific Context and Control AI-assisted development has rapidly transformed how engineers write code, collaborate, and ship software. GitHub Copilot, powered by OpenAI’s Codex and now evolving with GPT-5 capabilities, is at the center of this revolution — quietly sitting in your IDE, turning natural language prompts into working […] The article Unlock GitHub Copilot’s Full Potential: Why Every Repo Needs an AGENTS.md File was originally published on Build5Nines.

item.title: Introducing Data Ingestion Building Blocks (Preview)
item.description: When building AI applications, context is key. AI models have a knowledge cutoff and do not have access to your personal or company data by default. item.description: A straight look at what’s behind the keys We’ve all tried unlearning a keyboard shortcut - it feels like forgetting how to breathe. Muscle memory doesn’t mess around. We wrestle with this every time someone suggest a “quick” shortcut change. It’s not just editing a keybinding but navigating a history that makes Visual Stu Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/why-changing-keyboard-shortcuts-in-visual-studio-isnt-as-simple-as-it-seems

item.title: How do I check whether the user has permission to create files in a directory?
item.description: A customer wanted to accept a directory entered by the user and verify that the user has permission to create files in that folder. The directory itself might not even be on a local hard drive; it could be a DVD or a remote network volume. They tried calling Get­File­Attributes, but all they were told was that it was a direct Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20251203-00/?p=111836

The big narrative was about agents as partners in the development lifecycle, moving from tools that assist, to intell Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/engineering-at-microsoft/the-interaction-changes-everything-treating-ai-agents-as-collaborators-not-automation

item.title: Single File Test Suites in Dotnet Csharp
item.description: Introduction One of my favorite new features in .NET 10 is C# file-based apps (or file-based C# programs if you prefer). With this feature, we can create individual .cs files and then run them using dotnet run <file.cs>. On Unix OSes you can go even further and mark the files as executable and include a shebang (#!) directive as the first line to tell the OS what to run it with and then you can run the files directly without even calling dotnet run.

item.title: Securing Sensitive Mobile Operations with Device-Bound Request Signing
item.description: Mobile security goes beyond verifying user identity. If an attacker steals a valid token, how will your backend distinguish a legitimate request from one reproduced in an emulator or cloned environment? This is a gap in traditional authentication flows when applied to the mobile environment. By linking each request to hardware-backed keys g Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/blog/securing-sensitive-mobile-operations-with-device-bound-request-signing

This effort (codenamed "Project Corsa", and soon "TypeScript 7.0") Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/progress-on-typescript-7-december-2025

item.title: Use cd - in Powershell 7 to Return to Previous Directory
item.description: Introduction A command that many shells have had forever and that PowerShell has had for a long time as well is ‘cd -’ which means “change directory to previous folder”. This means you could do something like this: 1 2 3 4 5 6 cd c:\dev c:\dev cd c:\temp c:\temp cd - c:\dev This is quite handy in many situations. In particular, since I’ve modified my PowerShell Profile to NOT start in my users folder but instead to start in my c:\dev folder (from which I can easily get to any repo I may be working from), I very often find myself using cd - whenever I create a new terminal in the folder I want to be in such as when using VS Code.

item.title: dotInsights | December 2025
item.description: Did you know? Calling GC.Collect() explicitly forces the garbage collector to run and reclaim memory from unreachable objects. However, it’s generally discouraged to use this method in most applications because the garbage collector is highly optimized to run automatically. Forcing it can lead to performance issues by interrupting the normal optimization process. Welcome to dotInsights […] Link to article: https://blog.jetbrains.com/dotnet/2025/12/02/dotinsights-december-2025/

item.title: I Went to BazelCon 2025 – Here’s Everything You Need to Know
item.description: This year, BazelCon was held at the Omni Atlanta Hotel at Centennial Park for a very special occasion: the tenth anniversary of Bazel 🎉 For me, visiting from Europe, Atlanta made quite the first impression. The city felt bigger than anything I’ve seen back home, and with KubeCon happening right next door, the streets were […] Link to article: https://blog.jetbrains.com/clion/2025/11/bazelcon-2025/

item.title: What’s New in TeamCity 2025.11: AI Assistant, New Pipeline Features, Enhanced Server Encryption Settings, and More.
item.description: TeamCity 2025.11 introduces new build steps for pipelines, enhanced encryption settings, and a refreshed experience that makes powerful CI/CD workflows easier to create and manage. Here’s what’s new in this release. Introducing AI Assistant (Early Access) TeamCity is a true powerhouse, but mastering every one of its features can be challenging. To help you get […] Link to article: https://blog.jetbrains.com/teamcity/2025/11/teamcity-202511/

item.title: ReSharper and Rider 2025.3.0.3: A Fresh Set of Updates Released
item.description: Another set of updates for the 2025.3 versions of ReSharper and Rider has just been released. Let’s take a look at what’s been improved. ReSharper 2025.3.0.3 The most notable fix of this build is that extension methods from source-only NuGet packages are now recognized correctly in the editor and by InspectCode. [RSRP-502165]. You can find the […] Link to article: https://blog.jetbrains.com/dotnet/2025/11/27/resharper-and-rider-2025-3-0-3/

item.title: One Could Simply Add Nullability Check Support… Without Even Noticing It
item.description: (The Growing Pains of a Good Idea: What Happens After JSpecify Adoption Begins) The good news: JSpecify is finally here JSpecify adoption is accelerating. You don’t even need to “install” it – nullability support now arrives automatically with your dependencies. If you somehow missed the long history behind the JSpecify effort and want a quick […] Link to article: https://blog.jetbrains.com/idea/2025/11/one-could-simply-add-nullability-check-support-without-even-noticing-it/

item.title: Visualizing GitHub Audit Log in Microsoft Defender
item.description: [alert type="tip" heading="Tips"]In today’s rapidly evolving DevSecOps landscape, the need for real-time v Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/all-things-azure/visualizing-github-audit-log-in-microsoft-defender

item.title: Terraform + Azure Multi-Region Naming Convention across Azure Regions, Resources, and Terraform Modules
item.description: Imagine this: your application goes down in a major Azure region outage. DNS traffic shifts to the secondary region as designed. Terraform kicks off to scale the backup environment. Everything should just seamlessly work… but it doesn’t. Why? Because names don’t match. Storage accounts are globally unique. Key Vault names are different across regions. Resource […] The article Terraform + Azure Multi-Region Naming Convention across Azure Regions, Resources, and Terraform Modules was originally published on Build5Nines.

item.title: How Myriad Genetics achieved fast, accurate, and cost-efficient document processing using the AWS open-source Generative AI Intelligent Document Processing Accelerator
item.description: In this post, we explore how Myriad Genetics partnered with the AWS Generative AI Innovation Center to transform their healthcare document processing pipeline using Amazon Bedrock and Amazon Nova foundation models, achieving 98% classification accuracy while reducing costs by 77% and processing time by 80%. We detail the technical implementation using AWS's open-source GenAI Intelligent Document Processing Accelerator, the optimization strategies for document classification and key information extraction, and the measurable business impact on Myriad's prior authorization workflows.

item.title: How CBRE powers unified property management search and digital assistant using Amazon Bedrock
item.description: In this post, CBRE and AWS demonstrate how they transformed property management by building a unified search and digital assistant using Amazon Bedrock, enabling professionals to access millions of documents and multiple databases through natural language queries. The solution combines Amazon Nova Pro for SQL generation and Claude Haiku for document interactions, achieving a 67% reduction in processing time while maintaining enterprise-grade security across more than eight million documents. Link to article: https://aws.

item.title: Managed Tiered KV Cache and Intelligent Routing for Amazon SageMaker HyperPod
item.description: In this post, we introduce Managed Tiered KV Cache and Intelligent Routing for Amazon SageMaker HyperPod, new capabilities that can reduce time to first token by up to 40% and lower compute costs by up to 25% for long context prompts and multi-turn conversations. These features automatically manage distributed KV caching infrastructure and intelligent request routing, making it easier to deploy production-scale LLM inference workloads with enterprise-grade performance while significantly reducing operational overhead.
